questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of an ulcer on his penis for the past 12 days. The ulcer is painful and draining yellow purulent material. He returned from a study abroad trip to India 3 months ago. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a 2-cm ulcer with a necrotic base proximal to the glans of the penis. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lymphogranuloma venereum caused by L1, L2, and L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis manifests as a transient papule that is painless and heals rapidly without scarring. Painful suppurative lymphadenopathy is seen 2–6 weeks after the papule heals, with systemic symptoms like fever, malaise, and chills. This patient has a very painful lesion with regional lymphadenopathy and no systemic signs, making LGV unlikely.
Image Description:

Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).

The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis manifests with painless nodules that eventually ulcerate to form large, beefy-red lesions that bleed easily; regional lymph nodes are typically spared. This patient has a painful nonbleeding ulcer and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, making infection with Klebsiella granulomatis unlikely.
Image Description:

Coronal sulcus on an adult penis with three solitary, round, ulcerating lesions. This finding indicates granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries.

C) INCORRECT:

In primary syphilis, chancre appears at the site where Treponema pallidum enters the body and also typically manifests as a solitary ulcer but is painless and with indurated borders. Chancre can cause bilateral regional lymphadenopathy, however, it is usually nontender. This patient's painful sore with tender regional lymphadenopathy and purulent exudate indicates another diagnosis.
Image Description:

Localization: proximal penile shaft
Description: painless, superficial ulcer with indurated borders
Diagnosis: chancre of primary syphilis

D) INCORRECT:

Genital herpes caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV; typically HSV2) manifests with vesicular or ulcerative lesions localized on or around the genitals. They also often cause itching, tender lymphadenopathy, and burning pain in the affected area, along with systemic symptoms of fever and malaise. Although this man has tender lymph nodes, the absence of vesicles and the presence of a painful ulcer with purulent exudate make genital herpes an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

E) CORRECT:

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the gram-negative bacillus Haemophilus ducreyi. This condition manifests with a very painful lesion that is typically 2-cm in size and clearly demarcated with a greyish necrotic base. In men, a single lesion is common, while in women multiple lesions may be present. In addition, chancroid is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Treatment of chancroid is with single-dose oral azithromycin or intramuscular ceftriaxone.
Image Description:

There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.
questions.hint: The painful necrotic ulcers and lymphadenopathy indicate chancroid.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple painful, purulent ulcers she noticed on her vulva 2 days ago. The patient has not had fever or burning with urination. She has no history of similar lesions. She had a chlamydial infection at 17 years of age that was treated with antibiotics. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is sexually active with her boyfriend of 2 months and uses an oral contraceptive; they use condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg. Examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. There are 4 tender, purulent 1.5-cm ulcers with a necrotic base along the labia majora. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the gram-negative bacillus Haemophilus ducreyi. In women, chancroid manifests with multiple purulent lesions that are 1–2 cm in size, clearly demarcated with a greyish necrotic base, and typically very painful. In men, a single lesion is common. In addition, chancroid is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Treatment of chancroid is with single-dose oral azithromycin or intramuscular ceftriaxone.

B) INCORRECT:

Granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis manifests with painless nodules that eventually ulcerate to form large, beefy-red lesions that bleed easily; regional lymph nodes are typically spared. This patient shows nonbleeding ulcers and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, making infection with Klebsiella granulomatis unlikely.
Image Description:

Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infection

Multiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.

Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.

C) INCORRECT:

Genital herpes caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV; typically HSV2) manifests with vesicular or ulcerative lesions localized on or around the genitals. They also often cause itching, tender lymphadenopathy, and burning pain in the affected area, along with systemic symptoms of fever and malaise. Although this woman has tender lymph nodes, the absence of vesicles and the presence of painful ulcers with purulent exudate make genital herpes an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

D) INCORRECT:

In primary syphilis, chancre appears at the site where Treponema pallidum enters the body, and although multiple lesions are possible, chancre typically manifests as a solitary painless ulcer with indurated borders. Chancre can cause bilateral regional lymphadenopathy, but lymphadenopathy is also nontender. The multiple, painful sores with regional lymphadenopathy and purulent exudate in this patient indicate another diagnosis.
Image Description:

A round, ulcerative lesion with well-defined margins and a central induration is visible on the right labium majorum.

This finding is consistent with primary syphilitic chancre.

E) INCORRECT:

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) caused by L1, L2, and L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis manifests as a transient papule that is painless and heals rapidly without scarring. Painful suppurative lymphadenopathy is seen 2–6 weeks after the papule heals, with systemic symptoms like fever, malaise, and chills. This patient has multiple, very painful lesions with regional lymphadenopathy, but does not have any systemic signs, making LGV a less likely diagnosis.
questions.hint: The painful necrotic ulcers and lymphadenopathy suggest a sexually transmitted infection with a gram-negative organism.

questions.text: A previously healthy 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful lesion on his penis. The lesion appeared 2 days ago and has since grown in size. It is draining yellow purulent material. One week ago, he returned from a 1-month trip to Cambodia. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is sexually active with multiple female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Physical examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes L1, L2, or L3 causes lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). LGV initially manifests with small, painless, shallow genital ulcers that heal spontaneously without scarring. Approx. 2–6 weeks later, patients develop painful suppurative lymphadenopathy that may ulcerate (buboes) and systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, and chills). This patient's acutely painful lesion, lymphadenopathy, and absence of systemic signs are not characteristic of LGV.
Image Description:

A small, shallow ulcer is visible on the shaft of the penis (arrow).

This lesion is suggestive of early LGV caused by Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Infection with Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, which manifests with painless nodules that eventually ulcerate into large, beefy-red lesions that bleed easily. Regional lymphadenopathy is usually absent. This patient's acutely painful ulcer and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy make infection with K. granulomatis unlikely.
Image Description:

Coronal sulcus on an adult penis with three solitary, round, ulcerating lesions. This finding indicates granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection with Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which manifests with a solitary painless ulcer with indurated borders (a chancre) and bilateral painless regional lymphadenopathy. This patient's painful ulcer, tender regional lymphadenopathy, and purulent exudate make infection with T. pallidum unlikely.
Image Description:

Localization: proximal penile shaft
Description: painless, superficial ulcer with indurated borders
Diagnosis: chancre of primary syphilis

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with HSV (typically HSV2) causes genital herpes, which manifests with painful lymphadenopathy with multiple grouped painful vesicles and/or ulcers on or around the genitals. Patients also experience severe genital discomfort (e.g., itching and burning) and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever and malaise). This patient's solitary ulcer, purulent exudate, and lack of vesicles make HSV infection unlikely.
Image Description:

Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

E) CORRECT:

Infection with Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which typically manifests with an intensely painful, clearly demarcated lesion with a grey necrotic base and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Men usually present with a single lesion, while women often develop multiple synchronous lesions. H. ducreyi is endemic in tropical and subtropical regions (e.g., Cambodia) and rare in the United States. Chancroid is usually treated with a single dose of oral azithromycin or intramuscular ceftriaxone.

F) INCORRECT:

Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonorrhea, which is usually asymptomatic but can manifest with urethritis or epididymitis in men. Urethritis manifests with painful urination and spontaneous mucopurulent discharge from the urethral meatus, while epididymitis manifests with acute, painful, unilateral scrotal swelling. None of these symptoms are present in this patient. In addition, N. gonorrhoeae infection does not explain this patient's painful exudative ulcer or tender lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: This patient's painful and necrotic lesion with purulent discharge as well as tender lymphadenopathy following recent travel to a tropical region (i.e., Cambodia) is suggestive of chancroid.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man is evaluated for penile ulcers that developed one week ago, during a trip to the Caribbean. He initially noticed “red pimples” on his penis that then became painful ulcers. A few days later, he noticed a tender lump in his groin. He reports that during the trip, he had vaginal intercourse with sex workers and did not use condoms.
On examination, his vital signs are normal. There are several ragged-appearing, non-indurated, 1-cm ulcers over the shaft of the penis that bleed easily. A large and exquisitely tender lymph node is present over the right groin.
Which one of the following pathogens is the most likely etiologic agent in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, which usually manifests as painless, destructive, beefy-red, and highly vascular ulcerative lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

HSV causes painful ulcers that are usually shallow and vesicular and can be recurrent, but it is less typically associated with suppurative inguinal adenopathy than the most likely causal organism of this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum causes syphilis; the primary chancre is typically painless and indurated. Secondary syphilis typically causes a diffuse rash involving the hands and soles and condyloma latum (flat, broad, whitish, wart-like lesions) on mucous membranes.

D) CORRECT:

Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which is characterized by deep, painful, ragged-appearing penile ulcers and tender suppurative inguinal adenopathy. The ulcer associated with H. ducreyi begins as a tender, elevated bump or papule that becomes a pus-filled, open sore with eroded or ragged edges.

H. ducreyi is a significant cause of genital ulcer disease in parts of Africa and the Caribbean. Identification of the organism on special culture media is required for a definitive diagnosis. A probable diagnosis can be made if a patient has a typical clinical presentation (including one or more painful genital ulcers, as described in this patient), is found to have no evidence of Treponema pallidum infection on dark-field microscopy of the ulcer exudate or by serologic testing, and has a negative test for HSV performed on the ulcer exudate. See “Overview of sexually transmitted genital lesions” table.

Key learning point: Infection with Haemophilus ducreyi is characteristically associated with painful, ragged-appearing genital ulcers and tender suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis L-serovars causes lymphogranuloma venereum, which is characterized by short-lived, painless genital ulcers and painful suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents with a five-day history of a painful sore on the shaft of his penis. He also reports tender, enlarged groin nodes. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Examination reveals a foul-smelling ulcer with ragged undermined edges and a necrotic base. The inguinal lymph nodes are swollen and fluctuant on palpation.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary syphilis presents with a solitary, painless chancre that is firm and well-demarcated with a clean base. Regional lymphadenopathy is typically non-tender and rubbery. The painful, foul-smelling ulcer with ragged edges and necrotic base, along with tender, fluctuant lymph nodes, is atypical for syphilis.

B) CORRECT:

Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, manifests with painful genital ulcers that have ragged, undermined edges and a necrotic, foul-smelling base. It is often accompanied by tender, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy, which can progress to fluctuant buboes. The combination of a painful ulcerative lesion on the genitalia and painful, enlarged inguinal nodes with signs of abscess formation is characteristic of chancroid.

Key learning point: Chancroid is characterized by painful genital ulcers with ragged edges and necrotic bases, often accompanied by tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Granuloma inguinale, caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis, presents as a slowly progressive ulcer with a beefy red appearance and granular surface. It is typically painless with minimal lymphatic involvement. The acute, painful, foul-smelling ulcer with ragged edges and necrotic base, along with tender, fluctuant lymph nodes, is inconsistent with granuloma inguinale.

D) INCORRECT:

Genital herpes typically presents with clusters of small, grouped vesicles that evolve into superficial ulcers with a clean base. While herpes lesions are painful, they do not form a single, malodorous ulcer with ragged edges and necrotic center. Lymphadenopathy in herpes is usually mild and non-fluctuant.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 12-day history of a painful ulcer on his penis that is draining yellow purulent material. He returned from a study abroad trip to India 3 months ago. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.2°C, pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination reveals tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and a 2-cm ulcer with a necrotic base proximal to the glans of the penis. Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism?

Granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis manifests with painless nodules that eventually ulcerate to form large, beefy-red lesions that bleed easily; regional lymph nodes are typically spared. This patient has a painful nonbleeding ulcer and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, making infection with Klebsiella granulomatis unlikely.

Painful suppurative lymphadenopathy is seen 2–6 weeks after the papule heals, with systemic symptoms like fever, malaise, and chills. This patient has a very painful lesion with regional lymphadenopathy and no systemic signs, making LGV unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Genital herpes caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV; typically HSV2) manifests with vesicular or ulcerative lesions localized on or around the genitals. They also often cause itching, tender lymphadenopathy, and burning pain in the affected area, along with systemic symptoms of fever and malaise. E) CORRECT:

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the gram-negative bacillus Haemophilus ducreyi. This condition manifests with a very painful lesion that is typically 2-cm in size and clearly demarcated with a greyish necrotic base. In men, a single lesion is common, while in women multiple lesions may be present. In addition, chancroid is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Treatment of chancroid is with single-dose oral azithromycin or intramuscular ceftriaxone.

Key learning point: Chancroid presents as a painful genital ulcer with a necrotic base and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.
Image Description:

There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.
questions.hint: The painful necrotic ulcers and lymphadenopathy indicate chancroid.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to your clinic because of multiple painful, purulent ulcers on her vulva that she noticed 2 days ago. She has not had fever or dysuria. She has no history of similar lesions. She was treated for chlamydial infection at age 17. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is sexually active with her boyfriend of 2 months and uses an oral contraceptive; they use condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.2°C, pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg. On examination, she has tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and 4 tender, purulent 1.5-cm ulcers with a necrotic base along the labia majora. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the gram-negative bacillus Haemophilus ducreyi. In women, chancroid manifests with multiple purulent lesions that are 1–2 cm in size, clearly demarcated with a greyish necrotic base, and typically very painful. In men, a single lesion is common. In addition, chancroid is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Treatment of chancroid is with single-dose oral azithromycin or intramuscular ceftriaxone.

Key learning point: Chancroid presents as multiple painful, purulent genital ulcers with a necrotic base and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, most commonly caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

B) INCORRECT:

In primary syphilis, chancre appears at the site where Treponema pallidum enters the body, and although multiple lesions are possible, chancre typically manifests as a solitary painless ulcer with indurated borders. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) caused by L1, L2, and L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis manifests as a transient papule that is painless and heals rapidly without scarring. Painful suppurative lymphadenopathy is seen 2–6 weeks after the papule heals, with systemic symptoms like fever, malaise, and chills. This patient has multiple, very painful lesions with regional lymphadenopathy, but does not have any systemic signs, making LGV a less likely diagnosis.

Genital herpes caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV; typically HSV2) manifests with vesicular or ulcerative lesions localized on or around the genitals. They also often cause itching, tender lymphadenopathy, and burning pain in the affected area, along with systemic symptoms of fever and malaise. Although this woman has tender lymph nodes, the absence of vesicles and the presence of painful ulcers with purulent exudate make genital herpes an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: The painful necrotic ulcers and lymphadenopathy suggest a sexually transmitted infection with a gram-negative organism.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a 4-day history of genital pain and swelling. He is sexually active, and condom use is inconsistent. Physical examination shows a painful ulcer (shown in photograph) and bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Herpes simplex virus (HSV) polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and syphilis serology are negative. What is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Discharge with topical antibiotics and urology follow-up
Admit for wound debridement and infectious disease consultation
Discharge with doxycycline and primary care follow-up
Discharge with azithromycin and STI clinic follow-up
Admit for IV antibiotics and surgical consultation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are ineffective for chancroid, which requires systemic antibiotic therapy. This infection is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, and oral or parenteral antibiotics are required to achieve adequate tissue levels for treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Wound debridement is not indicated for chancroid ulcers, which heal with antibiotic therapy. Infectious disease consultation is not routinely needed for uncomplicated chancroid that can be managed with standard antibiotic regimens.

C) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is not a first-line treatment for chancroid. The recommended antibiotics are azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin. STI clinic follow-up is more appropriate than primary care follow-up because of contact tracing and partner management.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with a painful genital ulcer, tender lymphadenopathy, and negative HSV and syphilis testing, which is consistent with chancroid. Chancroid can be managed on an outpatient basis with oral azithromycin or ceftriaxone. STI clinic follow-up is appropriate for contact tracing and partner notification, which is essential for chancroid management.

E) INCORRECT:

Admission is not routinely required for uncomplicated chancroid. This condition responds well to outpatient oral antibiotic therapy. Surgical consultation is not indicated unless there are complications such as persistent fluctuant lymphadenopathy requiring drainage.
